newsitem.title: CHINA: China vows crackdown on textile transshipments.
newsitem.headline: China vows crackdown on textile transshipments.

text.p: China pledged on Thursday to step up a crackdown on illegal transshipments of textiles and urged the United States not to politicise their trade dispute by slashing China's 1996 textile and apparel quotas.

Li Dongsheng, a department head at the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, said illegal textile transshipments were a result of foreign business executives falsifying export permits and changing the logos of Chinese-made textiles on arrival in a third country, the International Business Daily said.
"We should have sufficient understanding and vigilance," Li said of the practice.
The ministry convened a meeting on Wednesday and decided to "continue to severely deal a blow to illegal textile transshipment activities", the newspaper said.

"At the same time, we are firmly opposed to ... (foreign) governments reducing China's quota without ample consultations, evidence or distinguishing where the responsibility lies ... politicising the problem," Li said.

In Washington last week, acting U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky announced punitive charges against China's 1996 textile and apparel quotas, citing transshipments of Chinese textiles in violation of a 1994 trade agreement.
An investigation by the U.S. Customs Service accused China of working to circumvent the agreement.

China denied the allegation and urged the United States to rescind the punitive action or risk retaliatory action. Beijing said the door was open for consultation to reach a conclusion satisfactory to both sides.
The punitive action was expected to cost China about $19 million.

The International Business News said China had punished 21 domestic and foreign companies for illegal textile transshipments since 1991, seizing their goods, rescinding quotas allocated by the government, imposing fines and revoking their business licences.
In February 1995 and in June this year, Beijing and Washington only narrowly avoided what would have been a bruising trade war over China allowing widespread copyright piracy to go unchecked.
